content:
EXISTING STRUCTURES
No structures have been successfully built on the map. Multiple recovery attempts were made to supply—and ultimately craft and place—a Lab at position (0.5, 2.5) for research support, but all placement operations failed due to missing inventory and resource shortages. Other facilities (for example, the furnaces used for iron and copper smelting at positions (5.0, 5.0) and (–27.0, –60.0)) were only employed as part of resource processing and were not created as new multi‐entity structures.

ERROR TIPS
• API call errors – When retrieving entities, incorrect parameters were used:
  - Using a keyword argument “radius” in get_entities resulted in an unexpected keyword error.
  - Passing positional arguments to get_entities when none are expected led to a “takes 0 positional arguments” error.
  Ensure the function’s signature is verified and call it using the appropriate parameters.
  
• Placement and inventory verification – Attempts to place a Lab at (0.5, 2.5) failed because no Lab was present in the inventory.
  Verify the availability of required inventory items before initiating placement commands.
  
• Handling null responses – Iterating over the result of get_entities sometimes produced a “NoneType object is not iterable” error.
  Always check for a null or None response before attempting to iterate over returned entities (or default to an empty collection).
  
• Resource and sub-ingredient shortages – Crafting failures for the Lab were triggered by missing sub-ingredients (such as iron-gear-wheels, electronic-circuits, copper-cables, and even basic smelted products like iron-plate and copper-plate).
  Confirm that all prerequisite items and intermediate production steps are fully satisfied before attempting to craft complex structures.
  
• Fallback error handling – Recovery routines that attempt to craft or place a Lab should include robust checks on both the inventory and response data, ensuring that fallback approaches (such as substituting an empty list when no entities are detected) are correctly implemented and trigger appropriate resource management adjustments.
